awd_titl_txt: MRI:  The Acquisition of a Flow Cytometer to Enhance Research and Training at South Carolina Undergraduate Institutions in the Upstate
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Furman University to support the acquisition of a flow cytometer to enhance research and training in the South Carolina Upstate. Flow cytometry is a powerful tool for the simultaneous analysis of multiple biological and/or chemical targets within cells or similarly sized objects. It possesses the speed, sensitivity, and robustness to analyze rare populations within large, heterogeneous samples, making it a critical analytical tool that will be used in faculty-led, student-centered research in the Biology, Chemistry, and Neuroscience programs at Furman, a research-active Primarily Undergraduate Institution (PUI). In addition, faculty and student research efforts at other regional PUIs will benefit from access to this equipment. Acquisition of the flow cytometer will enable the high-impact engagement of at least 50 students and faculty across the three participating institutions each year. Through multiple active NSF summer research programs, additional faculty and students from regional PUIs, HBCUs, two-year colleges, and first generation-serving institutions will directly benefit from access to the instrument. 

Faculty-led research programs serve as the cornerstone of Furman’s vision of engaged learning for undergraduates in the sciences. Acquisition of the flow cytometer will enable diverse research including (1) activation-induced chromatin decondensation in cells of the lymphocyte lineage; (2) polydiacetylene liposomes as sensors and imaging agents; (3) effects of reactive oxygen species fungi; (4) the development of novel PI3K inhibitors; (5) sex differences in the effects of high fat diet; (6) RNA binding proteins; and (7) stem cells biology. Faculty are committed to dissemination of their findings in presentations at national conferences and publications that include undergraduate co-authors in respected peer-reviewed journals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project funded the purchase of a state-of-the-art flow cytometer at Furman University. Furman is a research active Primarily Undergraduate Institution (PUI) that has established itself as a leader that supports research of several other PUIs in the region. The new flow cytometer replaced an outdated instrument that was no longer supported by the manufacturer. The flow cytometer purchased with this award is an instrument that allows scientists to analyze small objects (the size of cells or smaller) for up to 14 parameters simultaneously to include size, complexity and up to 12 additional user-defined parameters. The complexity of analyses is coupled with the instrument’s ability to analyze up to 30,000 events per second. These capabilities allow for analyses that were not possible with our previous instrument (e.g. studying rare populations of cells within a heterogeneous sample). Additionally, the instrument has an automation ability and is more user-friendly, making use of the instrument more amenable to undergraduates.

The COVID pandemic, which began shortly after the award was made, delayed the purchase and installation of the instrument by nearly one year. Despite this initial challenge, the flow cytometer has seen tremendous usage by users at Furman and other institutions. In its first full year of operation, the instrument has had a total of 34 users, illustrating the immediate impact of the instrument. Over the past three years, a total of 98 users (91 of whom were undergraduate students) have utilized the instrument as part of research or as part of course-related laboratory activities. Over the entire award period, the instrument has logged over 700 hours of operation. The instrument has supported a diverse array of projects led by Furman faculty including: activation-induced chromatin decondensation in cells of the lymphocyte lineage; polydiacetylene liposomes as sensors, drug delivery systems, and imaging agents; effects of reactive oxygen species on fluconazole drug resistance in fungi; the development of novel PI3K inhibitors as a chemotherapeutic drug; measuring the effects of environmental toxins on the brain; and RNA binding proteins that regulate intracellular drug accumulation. In addition, users from regional affiliate institutions and outreach programs have had access to the instrument. Finally, the instrument has been used in collaborative projects involving researchers at the Medical University of South Carolina and the University of Texas at Austin.

Perhaps the most significant outcome of this award is the exposure of undergraduate students to the research capabilities that the instrument presents. The flow cytometer is a centerpiece of a growing infrastructure of instrumentation at Furman University that enables undergraduate students to have access and training in the technologies that not only enhance their education but also allow them to make meaningful contributions to the research enterprise.
